text: the big emerging human rights issue for
this century is human trafficking but
human trafficking is a convoluted
euphemism it's better to call it what it
really is slavery the worst place for
this courage is India I travel to the
poor state of Bihar to see the problem
firsthand girls are kidnapped from poor
villages or easily transported across
the border from nearby Nepal anybody who
thinks that the word slavery is
hyperbole should meet someone whose life
is belong to pimps and traffickers I go
to a red-light district and I see women
like you who are smiling who are
reaching out sometimes who are dressed
nicely and sometimes they look happier
than if they were working in the fields
so are they really happy or really
unhappy red-light districts in Bihar are
filled with Horror Story after Horror
Story let me quickly tell you about one
of them Meena
Haseena she is truly a heroic woman who
has shown at one power even greater than
a slave traders greed is a mother's love
Meena was kidnapped from her village in
India by a trafficker when she was
perhaps 11 or 12 she remembers only that
it was well before she had begun to
menstruate
Mina was beaten and forced to accept a
fate as a prostitute every night Mina
was forced to have sex with ten to
twenty five customers Mina thus joined
the ranks of some 10 million children
prostituted around the world more in
India than in any other country I'm not
exaggerating when I say that the slave
plantations of the 21st century are the
brothels of India Mina's owners even
wanted to breed her so they wanted a
daughter more than a son she had two
children a boy and a girl but they were
taken from Mina shortly after they were
born the two children were raised apart
from Mina
the kids were kept as hostages to ensure
that their mother would not resist or
flee but a mother's love made Mina a
nuisance to her owners she tried to
alert the police that she and her kids
were being held captive the police
didn't lift a finger to help her Mina's
agitation did lead to one result her
owners decided to kill her Mina learned
of the plot and escaped to a town
several hours away
you ever wonder you know if maybe you
did the wrong thing if maybe this is the
custom you should just let it be totally
kabhi kabhi I Sam and me do Veda Howe
take my new coach Galatea or ahankhah
Ayesha hey SH al lado I will never
accept the prostitution of myself my
family my daughters or anybody as long
as I can live I can breathe in captivity
I could not say anything but now that
I'm free I will never succumb
don't cut yet Amir will do everything it
is not in our blood to be prostitute it
so why should be accepted Mina found
help from a terrific anti-trafficking
organization called apni op views for
coming here but they continue in spite
of all of this apni OP is run by a
former journalist named muchi red gupta
rooty recovered trafficking and was so
horrified by what she found that she
quit her job and devoted her life to
fighting the brothel owners routier got
the police to raid Mina's old brothel
and rescue her daughter from the flesh
trade that girl is now recovering in
hospital
as for the brothel it is still operating
the police have not arrested the main
traffickers Meena and her children
remain in great danger
but for now against all odds she is
reunited with her family we need to help
people like Meena Andrew Tara
they are the vanguard of a new global
abolitionist movement this is an issue
crying out for world leaders and
community groups alike to seize and run
with both the left and right are
marshalling forces to join the fight but
I'm afraid that the typical distractions
are gonna get in the way richer as you
know in the u.s. both left and right
have been engaged in the trafficking
issue but they tend to disagree about it
and almost every aspect whether do you
call them the people sex workers do you
call them prostitutes is this something
that should be banned is it something
that should be legalized and regulated
is this whole debate something that you
know is helpful to somebody like you
who's at the grassroots trying to fight
the problem first of all I find that the
left has become like the right and the
right has become like the left so all
these lines
because you know the responses are so
different from what I would expect from
the right or from the left and the
debate is sort of being carried on by
theoretical framers of the issue in
universities but a very few of them are
coming down to the grassroots and seeing
what the struggle is what little girls
are fighting for how bravely they are
resisting the traffickers or how much
they want a new life and the tenacity
with which they grab any opportunity or
chance they can get or how their mothers
are standing up to all the forces of
poverty of sexism of the caste system
and still trying to navigate in
existence and here you know it sounds
like a stupid idea
when people say legalize prostitution
because it seems that we will be not
even acknowledging the desire for change
that these little girls and these women
have and that is what is relevant the
whole debate about what should we call
this and what should we not call this
problem is irrelevant
the problem exists and we have to solve
it and we have to solve it in the best
interest of the child and the best
interest of the mother which is not to
fight for the right to be prostitutes
but the right to be rocket scientists
and teachers and doctors we shouldn't
allow political polarization and hangups
to get in the way of a united front
against sex slavery while people can
disagree about legalization of
prostitution as such everybody should be
able to agree that teenage girls
shouldn't be enslaved against their will
in brothels and that is the daily
reality in much of the world and that is
what we need to focus on in India for
the new york times i'm nicholas kristoff
